content.webTitle: Trump rejects ‘crap’ dossier on Russia ties | The minute

fields.headline: Trump rejects ‘crap’ dossier on Russia ties
fields.bodyText: Donald Trump dismissed as ‘fake news’ a private intelligence dossier (including descriptions of Moscow hotel bedroom scenes) on his alleged Russia ties. The dossier was published for the first time on Tuesday after being passed last year to the FBI. How the dossier surfaced It’s all fake news, it’s phony stuff, it didn’t happen … It was a group of opponents that got together, sick people, and they put that crap together. – Donald Trump What’s in the dossier The Guardian has learned that the FBI applied for a warrant from the foreign intelligence surveillance (Fisa) court over the summer in order to monitor four members of the Trump team suspected of irregular contacts with Russian officials. Read further It might take just a minute to catch up on the latest politics news. But good journalism takes time and costs money. If you like the Guardian’s coverage, please consider joining us by becoming a member for only $6.99 a month. Thanks for reading! Become a Guardian member Trump claimed he’d build a wall between himself and his business interests, which he said would be managed by his sons. “At the end of eight years ... if they do a bad job, I’ll say: ‘You’re fired,’” Trump joked. Ha. Will it prevent conflicts of interest? In a sudden about-face, Trump said “as far as hacking” during the presidential election, “I think it was Russia – but I think we also get hacked by other countries and other people.” Kremlin ridicules dossier If [Vladimir] Putin likes Donald Trump, guess what folks, that’s called an asset not a liability. Now, I don’t know if I’m going to get along with Vladimir Putin. I hope I do. But there’s a good chance that I won’t. And if I don’t, do you honestly believe that Hillary would be tougher on Putin than me? … Give me a break. – Donald Trump At his confirmation hearing, secretary of state nominee Rex Tillerson, the former ExxonMobil CEO, awkwardly resisted calling Putin a “war criminal” and refused to discuss his company’s record on climate change. Tough questions for Tillerson Senator Cory Booker and Congressman John Lewis spoke out against Jeff Sessions, Trump’s attorney general nominee, questioning his commitment to racial justice and equal rights. Sessions appears on track for confirmation. Senate grills Sessions
